clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Therapeutic Positioning and Oromotor Intervention in Oral Feeding Ability of Premature Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Safe and Efficient Oral Feeding Ability in Premature Infants: A Study on Indicators for Oral Feeding Readiness and The Effect of Therapeutic Positioning and Oromotor Intervention

brief_summary.textblock:
Indonesia is the fifth country with the highest number of premature infants in the world. Research has shown that as many as 40% to 70% of premature infants exhibit both immature and atypical feeding skills and those requiring respiratory support and those experiencing delays in beginning oral feeding are most often affected.
Many of premature infants have poorly developed suck and swallow mechanisms. The neurological immaturity, abnormal muscle tone, depressed oral reflexes, and difficulty in regulating state, can decrease the quality of infant's oral motor skills and the quantity of intake. For these reasons many high-risk infants are unable to tolerate oral feeding from birth and have difficulty making the transition from tube feedings to functional oral feeding. This transition to full oral feeding is an important competency for the infant to attain prior to discharge home. Delays in discharge are often secondary to feeding difficulties, leading to increased medical costs.
Currently a number of treatment strategies exist to facilitate oral feeding in premature infants. These include environmental/physical modifications such as eliminating external stimuli during feedings, using therapeutic nipples to manipulate flow rate, positioning and swaddling to support the motor system and improve flexion, and oral motor intervention including Non-nutritive sucking (NNS) stimulation and oral/perioral stimulation. There are known various methods of oral and perioral stimulations, and one of them is Fucile Oral Stimulation Program (2002). Recent study claimed that oral stimulations combined with non-nutritive sucking stimulation in premature infants for at least 10 days period could facilitate oral feeding ability.
The therapy of new method that will be studied in this research using a combination of physiological flexion in therapeutic positioning with specific swaddling techniques, oral stimulation, stimulation of synergistic movements, and stimulation of non-nutritive sucking using a special designed pacifier according to the size of premature infant's oral cavity.
The objective of this study is to know the time span required for premature infant to achieve safe and efficient oral feeding after new method intervention. Therefore, this new method expectedly can be used as a formula to improve oral feeding ability in premature infant.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study was designed as a double-blinded and randomized controlled trial, will be held from August 2021 until August 2022 in several hospitals in Jakarta area: dr. Cipto Mangunkusumo National Central General Hospital, Harapan Kita Women & Children's Hospital, Bunda Women & Children's Hospital, Pasar Rebo Regional General Hospital, Cengkareng Regional General Hospital, Eka Hospital BSD, Pondok Indah Hospital, Brawijaya Hospital Antasari, and Budi Kemuliaan General Hospital. Premature infants who has achieved oral feeding readiness will be recruited as participants and will be evaluated for oral feeding ability. Participant will be in semi-upright position, using peristaltic plus for low-birth-weight pacifier in SS size. The volume of fluids feed will be decided based on neonatologist's assessment.
Participant is stated to achieve safe and efficient oral feeding if participant is able to swallow more than 30% of the volume set by the neonatologist for the first 5 minutes at a rate of more than or equal to 1.5 ml / minute and without signs of aspiration. If the results of the evaluation show that the participant has not been able to achieve safe and efficient oral feeding, the participants will be randomly divided into 2 groups for intervention: New method and Fucile method. The number of sample size calculated for each group is 93 subjects.
Both interventions will be given once a day (in up to 10 days). After each intervention is done, participant will be evaluated for safe and efficient oral feeding. If the participant has already fulfilled the criteria in safe and efficient oral feeding, intervention will end. If participant has not fulfilled the criteria, intervention will be continued. However, if the participant became unstable after given each intervention, then intervention will be halted and will be repeated again in the next feeding schedule. After 3 consecutive trials and the participant is still unstable while given intervention, then the participant will be put in drop out category.
Statistical analysis will be conducted using SPSS ver. 20.0. The level of significance was set at <0.05. Interim analysis will be conducted in this research and will be done in three steps:
1. Basic data analysis for comparing distribution between two intervention groups with descriptive analysis.
2. Bivariate analysis using chi-square.
3. Multivariate analysis using logistic regression if there are incomparable basic data variables.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Premature infants at 28 to 32 weeks of gestational age and has achieved oral feeding readiness will be evaluated for oral feeding ability. Infants who have not succeeded in safe and efficient oral feeding will be divided into 2 groups for intervention: New method and Fucile method.

primary_outcome.measure: Time Span to Achieve Safe and Efficient Oral Feeding After New Method Intervention
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 10 days after the first New method intervention
primary_outcome.description: Time span is measured in days. New method intervention will be given once a day. After New method intervention is done, participant will be evaluated for safe and efficient oral feeding. If the participant has already fulfilled the criteria in safe and efficient oral feeding, intervention will end. If participant has not fulfilled the criteria, intervention will be continued in up to 10 days.

primary_outcome.measure: Time Span to Achieve Safe and Efficient Oral Feeding After Fucile Method Intervention
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 10 days after the first Fucile method intervention
primary_outcome.description: Time span is measured in days. Fucile method intervention will be given once a day. After Fucile method intervention is done, participant will be evaluated for safe and efficient oral feeding. If the participant has already fulfilled the criteria in safe and efficient oral feeding, intervention will end. If participant has not fulfilled the criteria, intervention will be continued in up to 10 days.

arm_group.description: This intervention will be given once a day (in up to 10 days), 30 minutes before feeding schedule based on the neonatologist. Each session of intervention will take time about 18 minutes.
This intervention will be given once a day (in up to 10 days), 30 minutes before feeding schedule based on the neonatologist. Each session of intervention will take time about 15 minutes.

intervention.description: Physiological flexion in therapeutic positioning, oromotor stimulation (will be repeated 3 times for each regio), stimulation of synergistic movements, and stimulation for non-nutritive sucking by using special designed pacifier for premature infant.
Oral stimulation and non-nutritive sucking stimulation using usual pacifier.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Premature infants (28 to 32 weeks of gestational age) after medical condition is stable from assessment by neonatologist.
- Parent/guardian give consent to participate
Exclusion Criteria:
- Craniomaxillofacial malformation
- Neonatal asphyxia with 5-minute APGAR score is less than 7
- Grade 3 and 4 intraventricular hemorrhage
- Using endotracheal tube

overall_official.affiliation: Faculty of Medicine, University of Indonesia

facility.name: Dr. Cipto Mangunkusumo National General Hospital
